Captain Dennis Dearborn.Action: Agrees to keep ground crews working all night despite hoping to give them a break.
Engages seriously with news about planes and shows concern by hurrying to the balcony.
Calls the arriving airmen 'ordinary men' to emphasize their humility.
Responds stiffly to interview, never smiles or relaxes, reacts coldly to Bruce's teasing tone about his girlfriend.
Tries to share the excitement and responsibility of being a pilot with the Rookie Lieutenant, attempting to connect and prepare him.
Notices the Rookie Lieutenant's anxious departure and feels alienated and alone, showing sensitivity to social rejection.
Walks across the field alone with a beer instead of joining the group having fun, indicating social withdrawal or discomfort rather than warmth in interaction.
Approaches his ground crew chief Les Enright and inquires about his work on the plane, demonstrating responsibility and friendly directness.
Questions maintenance details and tries to ensure the plane is in good condition before flight, showing attentiveness and responsibility.
Confronts Les sharply and somewhat impatiently, but does not apologize for possibly overreacting, indicating a lapse in interpersonal diplomacy but not necessarily in technical competence.
Physically notices a dark red pool (implying injury or a serious problem) but only steps away without immediate decisive action shown in the excerpt.
Performs a ritualistic farewell to the plane, showing emotional attachment and respect, but this is more personal than an indicator of skill or competence.
Approaches the pale, woozy Rookie in the latrine, offers reassurance, and tries to calm his nerves.
Shows genuine affection and a brotherly attitude towards his men, expressing that he is used to being with them and cares for them deeply.
Sitting at a table with his men but appearing remote and lost in his own thoughts, deeply considering the risks ahead for his men.
Does not engage actively or cheerfully with his men during a casual moment, showing emotional weight and possible distraction.
Thanks the sergeant politely when woken up early for mission.
Inquires about missing crew member Phil Lowenthal.
Does not reprimand or scold Val for improvising an excuse about Phil.
Responds briefly and affirmatively to Sergeant's encouragement ('Will do').
Chosen to lead the mission despite knowing the navigator is ill, showing trust in his leadership.
Not intervening or addressing the dangerously impaired state of the navigator, allowing potential risk to the mission.
Greets men in the mess hall with a friendly tone, asks how they are doing this morning.
Watches Val retrieve the silverware box he knocked over but does not assist or comment.
Acknowledges the shared nervousness by saying 'I guess we've all got the jitters this morning,' indicating understanding and empathy.
Walks off after brief exchange without addressing the accident or checking on others.
Listens attentively to the briefing with a look of shock and concern.
Does not openly challenge or argue about the dangerous new mission despite visible concern.
Insists the Memphis Belle has to go to meet the quota despite losing a plane, showing disregard for the lives of men.
Informs the crew clearly about the delay due to cloud cover and instructs them to standby.
Uses the delay period productively by encouraging the crew to double-check and prepare thoroughly for the mission.
Directs Luke to perform a detailed pre-flight check despite distractions or frustration within the crew.
Calms down the crew during their nervousness and conflict, telling them to relax and be more like Phil.
Encourages Danny not to be shy and to share his poetry with the group, creating a supportive environment.
Shows a visible emotional response, being particularly struck by Danny's poem, indicating empathy and sensitivity.
Hesitates before asking Luke if he would choose to go or stay, showing concern and seeking input.
Gives Val permission to arm his bombs promptly and without hesitation.
Does not intervene in the tense exchange between Val and Phil, allowing Val to maintain focus on his task.

Acknowledges position and rally point precisely and calmly ('Captain, we're exactly five miles south southwest of Great Yarmouth. This is the rally point. We're in formation.'), then confirms to crew confidently ('Okay, boys, we're on our way.')
Gives careful safety instructions to the crew, emphasizing care to prevent injury and loss of fingers.
Reminds crew to check oxygen masks to prevent passing out, showing concern for their wellbeing.
Encourages the crew to work together and stay alert, aiming for their best performance.
Allows the crew to listen to a friendly radio program to lighten the mood, but sets clear limits.
Calmly instructs crew to keep their minds on the job, work together, and stay alert, demonstrating leadership and focus.
Allows light-hearted radio entertainment but sets clear boundaries ('But when I say that's enough...'), showing balanced judgment and control.
Orders the crew to test their guns promptly despite radio communication issues.
Joins in the laughter and accepts friendly teasing about ordering others around, showing good-natured tolerance.
Calmly instructs his crew to hold their fire and conserve ammunition, showing responsible care and consideration for the group's welfare.
Commands crew to hold fire until the enemy is in range to conserve ammunition.
Lightheartedly jokes about ordering others around, showing ability to maintain morale.
Firmly instructs crew to hold fire until in range, preventing waste of ammunition.
Directs Luke calmly to do his job during chaotic combat.
Encourages crew members to keep communicating during crisis calmly ('Keep calling them out!', 'Call in!', 'Keep calling in!') and urges them to hold on together facing danger.
Immediately checks on crew status after Phil is wounded and insists on quick communication.
Maintains professional command tone without overt empathy while crew reacts to injury and blood.
Commands the crew to call in immediately, maintains situational awareness and quickly organizes damage assessment and enemy location calls.
Clearly communicates changes in formation and timing of bombing runs, showing strategic coordination.
Gently asks Rascal not to tie up the intercom despite Rascal's insistence, showing consideration for others' communication needs.
Responds with quiet enjoyment and participates in group laughter at Rascal's joke, indicating friendly and warm group interactions.
Interrupts the jovial atmosphere to remind men about the seriousness of their situation with a firm but caring tone, balancing warmth with responsibility.
Shows emotional response to heartfelt letters from families of fallen airmen, indicating empathy and understanding of their sacrifices.
Refuses to authorize a homecoming party, emphasizing duty and results over relaxation or celebration.
Delegates responsibility by calmly instructing Val to assist with Jack and Gene to take care of him despite the critical moment close to the bomb run.
Shows awareness of priorities and crew safety under pressure by managing multiple tasks during combat.
Shows concern by directly asking Rascal if he is really okay after flak hits his turret.
Keeps a calm, matter-of-fact tone and offers practical information about flak jackets and bomb run procedure, reassuring crew.
Calmly assesses and reassures others when blood sprays in cockpit, helps defuse panic with rational behavior and humor
Focuses on mission with stern commands, does not display overt friendliness or emotional warmth in stressful situation
Insists on completing the bombing run to hit the factory despite dangerous conditions, overriding autopilot and risking crew safety.
Affirms his authority calmly to reassure the crew during a tense moment.
Takes command decisively, overrides autopilot to make a difficult decision to go around again despite risk.
Insists on bombing the target even when visibility is zero, potentially exposing the plane to danger.
Grabs Phil's hand to prevent him from pushing the bomb release button prematurely, showing concern and restraint.
Firmly rebukes Luke for dismissing the danger to civilians, emphasizing the importance of avoiding innocent casualties.
Speaks directly and honestly to the crew about their mission and its hardships, showing realism but also shared responsibility.
Does not look up at the incoming fighter, letting others handle the threat.
Reluctantly allows Luke to take action despite expressing doubt about others helping.
Doesn't react to imminent fighter attack in cockpit; stays focused and unflustered as danger passes overhead.
Questions whether others can help with tail gunner's ammo problem but ultimately permits Luke to intervene quickly.
Turns control over to bombardier for the bomb run, communicates planned evasive maneuvers clearly to Luke to prepare him.
Looks astonished and seems touched by Luke’s trust and support, reflecting appreciation and openness.
Watches the bomb delivery carefully, then manually flips off the autopilot and takes control of the plane, confidently declaring 'Now we're flying for ourselves.'
Responds calmly and quickly to a sudden explosion that violently rocks the plane by giving a clear command 'Call in!'
Orders Val to go back and help the injured Danny despite fighters being everywhere, showing decisiveness and prioritization under pressure.
Maintains composure under heavy attack and directs crew members calmly and clearly.
Speaks quietly and comfortingly to Luke, trying to ease his burden and fears.
Maintains composure and gives clear instructions during a dangerous situation, showing care for crew safety.
Tries to think of something to say to make a troubled crew member feel better but stops, unable to express fully.
Takes decisive action to save the plane while warning crew and working cooperatively with Luke.
Monitors situation closely and communicates clearly with crew to keep them informed and safe.
Thanks Luke sincerely after the fire is put out, showing appreciation and respect.

Takes decisive control by initiating a dive to blow out the fire despite risks, carefully monitors airspeed and advises leveling the plane before exceeding limits, works collaboratively with Luke to pull out of the dive, communicates clearly to the crew about their status.
No direct actions or statements in this excerpt; absence of decisive leadership or intervention during critical medical emergency on board is a negative indicator.
Supports Val's decision as doctor and insists on no argument, defers to Val's judgment.
Allows tension to escalate between Phil and Val without intervening directly or calming the situation.
Agrees to proceed with the risky plan proposed by Val and firmly commands that his decision is to be followed without argument.
Flips switch to sound alarm and commands crew to prepare for crash landing, taking control in a crisis.
Holds control wheel tightly, aiming the plane carefully towards the runway during a dangerous landing.
Grips the control wheel tightly and focuses on landing the damaged plane despite the crisis.
Maintains control of the plane during a loss of engine and manages to pull up the nose and complete landing gear extension at the last moment, preventing a crash.
Grips control wheel tight and commands flaps immediately after engine failure, showing quick reaction and decisive action.
Smiles and pats the Adjutant's arm affectionately.
Just sits in the cockpit after landing while others move around.
Appears with the bottle of champagne, initially grim but then lightens the mood by jubilantly popping the cork and dousing the crew, helping to ease tension before the photograph.
Responds promptly and professionally to the higher command despite bad news, commits to having ground crews work all night.
Appears visibly shaken by the news but continues to fulfill his duty, showing resilience under pressure.
Demonstrates situational awareness by using binoculars to monitor arriving planes closely.
Sits stiffly and seriously during an interview, showing no relaxation or smiling, indicating a focused and professional demeanor.
Responds firmly and respectfully to a casual or slightly flippant question about his personal life, demonstrating control and seriousness.
Insists on keeping the crew focused on their jobs and withholding news about fame until the right time, demonstrating control and prioritization.
Uses a firm 'Because I said so' response to justify his decision, which may suggest a reliance on authority rather than explanation.
No direct actions or statements by Captain Dennis Dearborn in the excerpt; primarily interaction among other characters sorting belongings of a dead man.
No direct actions, statements, or internal thoughts by Dearborn are present in the excerpt to assess competence.
Takes Phil's glass and pulls him toward the dance floor, encouraging social engagement.
Tries to describe the excitement and responsibility of being a pilot to a naive rookie but is inarticulate and fails to connect.
Attempts to explain the gravity and excitement of flying to a rookie, showing awareness of his responsibilities and emotional realities of combat flying.
Is inarticulate and unable to communicate effectively with the rookie lieutenant, who becomes anxious and tries to escape the conversation.
Identifies an issue with his plane’s maintenance and engages with the ground crew chief to ensure it is addressed.
Admits to having jumped on Les too fast but chooses not to apologize.
Speaks affectionately and sincerely to the plane, showing fondness and respect.
Stops the Rookie and other rookies from cheering prematurely at the event to avoid bad luck, showing awareness and care for the group's wellbeing.
Is not mentioned or actively involved in the described scene, which focuses on other characters' social interactions and reactions.
Responds promptly and willingly to an order with confidence (says 'Will do' and starts to get up).
Comes in to remind Phil and Val to keep quiet about 'you know what', indicating awareness and proactive leadership.
Takes a break (goes for chow) while the other officers remain in a tense environment, possibly showing trust or delegation but could be seen as absence during stress.
Keeps calm and composed in a tense, jittery environment; maintains professionalism by focusing on the briefing and team readiness.
Acknowledges the team's nervousness but does not overreact or lose command presence.
Walks off after noticing a minor disturbance (Phil causing a commotion), showing some detachment instead of immediately addressing it.
Insists on completing the mission despite losing a plane, deciding the Memphis Belle 'has to go' to meet the quota.
Demonstrates authoritative command by firmly stating 'I'm in command here and I've made my decision!'
Appears emotionally detached or overly focused on mission goals, as Bruce accuses him of caring more about quota than men’s lives.
Speaks with quiet force and feeling, carefully hiding his anxiety and anguish; expresses sincere concern for the crew, wishing them safety and promising to not rest until they are back.
Delivers a calm, focused, and heartfelt briefing to the crew, maintaining control of his emotions and inspiring confidence.
Shows anxiety and anguish internally but carefully conceals it to maintain morale.
Does not visibly lose composure or fail to provide clear instructions during crucial moments.
Systematically checks off important flight systems on a clipboard before takeoff, ensuring all are off as expected.
Responds calmly to operational delays and uncertainty about weather and target conditions without showing frustration.
Opens side window to communicate promptly and clearly with the Lieutenant delivering a critical update.
Encourages the men to use downtime productively by double-checking all equipment and making the mission their best yet.
Reprimands Bruce firmly, stating he won't tolerate insubordination and threatens arrest to maintain order before takeoff.
Engages calmly with incoming intelligence about weather updates, indicating situational awareness and decision-making readiness.
Calms down the nervous and jumpy crew by telling them to relax and be more like Phil.
Encourages Danny to share his poetry despite his hesitation, showing supportive leadership and emotional intelligence.
Is particularly struck by the poem, indicating reflective understanding of his men's feelings and morale.
Responds promptly to the Lieutenant's call to prepare for takeoff, demonstrating readiness and responsiveness.
Hesitates while holding clipboard and pencil before asking Luke a decisive question about whether to go or stay.
Flips a switch on the pilot's control panel following the takeoff signal and preflight checks.
Pushes on the control wheel calmly and prevents a collision with another plane in zero visibility, acting quickly and without panic.
Offers hot soup to Virge after noticing his injury.
Carefully delegates control of the plane to Luke briefly, showing trust and consideration.
Delegates control to Luke temporarily to manage cockpit tasks while he attends to other duties calmly (prepares and offers soup to injured Virge).
Calmly handles minor injuries and attends to crew needs without panic or disorganization.
Gives detailed, clear instructions over the intercom about glove use to prevent freezing fingers.
Reminds crew to check masks for frozen saliva to avoid oxygen blockage and passing out.
Instructs crew to keep intercom communication short and efficient to maintain clarity.
Issues a timely warning about approaching enemy territory and instructs crew to be on guard and call out fighters immediately.
Offers his crew to come work for his family furniture business after the war.
Immediately withdraws his offer when met with silence, saying 'Like I said, don't give it a thought....'
Intently flying the plane, maintaining focus on piloting duties.
Offers his family furniture business as an option for crew after the war, demonstrating leadership and care for team welfare.
Sheepishly retracts his offer after silence, showing some social awkwardness or uncertainty.
Orders gunners to hold fire until enemies are in range, preventing waste of ammunition.
Calmly instructs crew to call out enemy positions and focus on their roles during chaotic combat.
Interrupts Rascal to prevent tying up the intercom, demonstrating situational awareness and prioritization.
Keeps the crew focused by stopping the joking and reminding them the enemy is out there.
Requests navigator for position and processes map information accurately, showing awareness of enemy territory.
Firmly insists on discipline and adherence to protocol by not authorizing a homecoming party despite pressure, showing focus on mission and order.

Shows emotional control initially but also uses emotional impact (letters from bereaved families) to impress seriousness of the situation on subordinates, demonstrating situational awareness and leadership.
Interrupts and physically restrains Bruce to assert authority and keep the conversation on track, signaling confident command presence.
Refuses to acknowledge or engage directly with Bruce's criticism or concerns beyond enforcing his orders, which may suggest limited flexibility in leadership style.
Urgently instructs crew members to secure their parachutes despite discomfort, showing concern for their safety.
Warns crew to make sure parachutes are ready despite difficult circumstances.
Firmly insists Rascal wear the safety strap even though it is uncomfortable.
Speaks quietly, with humility, acknowledging responsibility and asking for help from other captains.
Takes control of the plane as it loses speed and altitude, communicates calmly and clearly with group, accepts responsibility to lead the formation and encourages others to be alert and focused.
Shows humility and sober awareness of the responsibilities involved, communicates with a clear plan and request for teamwork.
Keeps calling out enemy positions and checks on the status of his crew after flak hits the turret, showing vigilance and concern.
Maintains rational thinking and quickly assesses the situation after a sudden attack injures crew members, trying to identify who is hit despite the bloody chaos.
Shows confidence and calmness under extreme stress, refusing to panic and attempting to keep others calm.
Relies on reason rather than panic during a confusing and violent moment.
Calmly directs crew members to handle emergency fuel leak and encourages teamwork to save fuel.
Upon discovering a large hole and fuel leak, immediately delegates tasks to crew members to try to manage the situation (orders Virge to use fuel transfer pump and instructs Luke to assist).
Remains focused during crisis, prioritizing saving fuel and coordinating crew efforts despite the damage and danger.
No hesitation or panic shown when the plane is severely damaged and fuel is leaking rapidly; takes prompt action.
Encourages the crew to stay alert and focused, emphasizing pride in doing the job right.
Wipes away bets written on the window, signaling seriousness and readiness to focus.
Maintains composure under pressure, exchanging a meaningful look with Luke before breaking it to continue the mission.
Asserts control strongly by telling others to leave him alone and to let him do his job.
Delegates bomb run control to bombardier, flips autopilot on to maintain steady flight during critical moment.
Instructs Luke to prepare for evasive action after bombing, demonstrating planning and situational awareness.
Appears momentarily dazed and removes oxygen mask to talk, which may indicate stress but continues to fulfill command duties.
Remains physically steady and focused while his hand trembles on the autopilot switch during a critical bombing run, indicating controlled composure under pressure.
Relies on crew members' inputs without directly acting when Val hesitates at the bombsight, showing measured trust in team but some withholding of direct command.
Calls for ball turret to call in amidst intense combat, attempting to maintain communication and control.
Orders others to call in again after the plane is jolted hard, trying to coordinate the crew's response.
Instructs Val to go help the injured Danny despite intense danger, shows concern for crew member's wellbeing.
Offers reassurance to Luke about Danny's condition, attempting to calm and support him.
Does not force Val to act, allows hesitation, and doesn't reprimand his fear openly.
Speaks quietly and comfortingly to Luke to calm him down under stress.
Gives clear, correct instructions to cut fuel, feather prop, and use fire extinguisher on engine fire.
Responds with urgency and tactical thinking when instrument panel is damaged by bullets and fire spreads.
Coordinates with crew to assess situation and makes decisions rapidly under pressure.
Has to rely on Luke to pull out of dive, indicating some reliance on subordinate for critical maneuvers.
Advises the crew to throw out unnecessary weight to lighten the plane when running on two engines.
Looks to his crew for advice and support (Luke puts a hand on Dennis's shoulder), then breathes a sigh of relief when reassured.
Calmly commands his men to look alive and face the fighters, maintaining composure.
Shows a flicker of panic in his eyes when questioned about the situation with thrown-out guns.
Responds honestly about uncertain fuel status, 'I don't know. I guess we'll find out.'
Calmly assesses the landing gear problem and gives clear instructions to manually lower the wheel, coordinating team efforts.
Quickly assesses the landing gear failure and instructs the crew to attempt a manual lowering of the wheels while preparing for a belly landing.
Maintains calm under pressure and coordinates crew actions in a critical mechanical failure situation.
Flips a switch to sound an alarm bell and commands the crew to take crash landing positions.
Grips the control wheel tightly and skillfully directs the plane toward the base and runway despite having only one wheel down.
Appears with a grim expression, causing crew unease, then suddenly bursts with joy, spraying champagne on the crew, creating laughter and camaraderie.
